biogHist.p: Christina or Chirsty MacInnes was born in 1806, daughter of Dugald MacInnes, crofter, and Effy or Oighrig née MacInnes. By 1841 she was living as a cottar with her widowed mother and her sister Mary (1818–95) at 9 Hacleit. In 1852 Mary had a natural son Dugald by William MacAulay: he took over the croft after the previous tenants moved to Lìonacleit in 1879.

Alexander Carmichael recorded Cairistìona nighean Dùghaill on 16 June 1876, possibly at his own house in Creag Goraidh. He describes her as ‘bean bhoc[hd] a bhios a sniomh dhan mhnaoi agam’ (‘a poor woman who spins for my wife’): in other words, one of the women who was involved in Mary Frances’ ‘Home Industries’ charity work. She sang for him what appears to be a song by a betrayed lover, then stray lines from the beginning of the Fenian ballad about Conall [Gulban], and a recommendation to consult ‘Donul Curri S[outh] Lochboisdale’ [CW150/84-85]. Chirsty MacInnes may also have recited the items which follow: two apparently related prayers, Ùrnaigh Togail an Teine, and A Dhé fadaidh féin ’nam chridhe a-steach, the saying ‘Bu mhath an t-saighdearachd mur bhi na blàir’, and the word Aithealag, éibhleag, translated as ‘small peat fire’ [CW150/86-91].

From the purple and black pencils used in this recording session, it’s clear that Carmichael thereupon opened another notebook and continued taking down items from Chirsty MacInnes: the well-known and lengthy religious hymn Laoidh Dhùghaill Liosadair [CW119/57], a version of the prayer before sleep Laighidh mi a-nochd [CW119/58], as well as, perhaps, some remarks on the story behind the song Laoidh na h-Ighne which Carmichael had taken down from Duncan MacDonald, Snaoiseabhal, some five years previously (probably after she herself had sung it), and the phrase Bheir bumailear breith ach có bheir ceart[as?] [CW119/60].
Christina MacInnes died on 17 February 1894 of ‘asthma [and] old age’. Her death certificate was witnessed by her nephew Dugald MacInnes or MacAulay.

Alexander Carmichael ascribes to Christina MacInnes Coisrig Cadail, a Sleep Consecration [CG i, 80–1] which has a few points of contact with her own prayer before sleep; another sleep prayer Laighim am Leabaidh [ibid., 94–5]; and a description of how to set the iomairt (cloth striped lengthwise): Suidheachadh na h-Iomairt [ibid., 302–3].

From notes made concerning the projected content of the volume which would become Carmina Gadelica, Alexander Carmichael certainly considered ascribing to her Ora Turais (‘Ionnlai mi m aodan’) and the cattle charm ‘Siubhal coire siubhal coille’ [CW124 fo.3]; also Laoidh Dhughaill Liosadair, the prayer before sleep Laighidh mise a-nochd, as well as Laoidh na h-Ighne, this last under the title Binneach nam Beann [ibid. fos.6, 8]; and finally the charm Achlasan Chaluim Chille [ibid. fo.9]. If these ascriptions are correct, she well merited his tribute to her in a footnote to his list of reciters: ‘She had an immense amount of old lore, runes, and stories of great literary interest’ [CG ii, 375].

Although no items ascribed to Christina’s sister Mary appear in extant field notebooks, Carmichael clearly recorded from her. Her name is given as the informant for Ora Buadh [‘Cumraig Dhe is Dhomhnach’] in the draft Carmina contents [CW124 fo.3], while in the printed volumes she is cited as the source for An Liuthail (‘The Lustration’) [CG i, 58–9], as well as information about the loireag (‘a small mite of womanhood that does not belong to this world, but to the world thither’) on Beinn Mhór [ibid. ii, 320–1].

Again, in the drafts Christina’s nephew Dugald MacAulay (1852–1910) is given as the source for two charms: a Sian (‘An sian chuir Moir air a Mac’) and a version of the well-known bone-healing charm beginning Chaidh Brìde a-mach [CW124 fo.9]. These are both ascribed to him in Carmina Gadelica [CG ii, 18–19, 36–7], with the additional footnote: ‘He very kindly showed me the rites for curing the sprain and the red pleura and for counteracting the evil eye’ [ibid. 379n.6].
On 4 September 1906 Alexander Carmichael would record from Dugald MacAulay the song Cuist Eònachain [CW244 fos.139–40].

Dugald MacAulay, who ‘has a reputation in the island as a good storyteller’ [Angus Macmillan and Taigh Eachdraidh Bheinn na Faghla, Benbecula Donors in Carmina Gadelica (Balivanich, 2007), 21], is given as the source for a number of other items printed in later volumes of Carmina Gadelica: Altachadh, or Altachadh Shomhairle; Guidhe Turais (‘He learned it from his mother and from her sister, who lived with his mother. These two old women had innumerable hymns, songs, stories and fables, sayings and proverbs, full of wisdom and beauty, almost all of which died with them.’); Am Beannachadh Turais (‘The reciter … said that he always recited this little prayer to himself, ‘fo m’anail’, ‘under my breath’, when he went upon a journey, however short the distance, however small the matter of his errand’), Beannachadh Taimh; Eòlas Faireimidh (‘Charm for the Evil Eye’); and Teab an t-Sionnaich [ibid. iii, 54–5, 178–9, 180–1, 338–9; iv, 170–1, 248].

To the first of these is appended the description: ‘MacAulay is an old man, full of old songs and hymns, runes and incantations, fairy stories and strange beliefs. These he heard from his aunt and mother, who were full of song and story, natural and supernatural, and of old lore of the most curious kind. … He said that Somhairle Mac Calmain was a good man, moving about doing no harm, asking nothing and always getting enough. In his travels he was always crooning these little hymns to himself. This description might fit MacAulay himself, save that he seldom leaves his wind-swept moorland home.’
